bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, April 12, 1923

div1.p: Hanson writes that he doubts there is yellow fever in Colombia. He discusses the differences between his private practice and working for the public health service.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, April 12, 1923
div1.opener:
Miss;
Hanson
HENRY HANSON, M. D.
L A B O R A T O R Y
460 ST. JAMES BLDG.
JACKSONVILLE, FLORIDA
April 2, 1923.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I thank you for your letter in regard to Columbia, and
the news of the new outbreak in that country. It does seem rather puzzling
for yellow fever to break out there now after so many years of supposed free-
dom from the disease. To me it scarcely seem logical that it can be a new
outbreak. Is it not possible that it can be an instance of travelling from
one place to another where, if it has been recognized, it has been kept quiet
like our Peruvian friends tried to do? From my interviews with Columbians
aboard ship it seemed that they were not at all disposed to declare that
Columbia had anything even suspicious.

I do not know enough about Columbia and the density of population
or the proximity of one town to another to be able to form any opinion as
to the case with which infection could spread there. The climate of course
is ideal for the fever, and I am almost sorry that I am not going to take
a hand in it.

I received a telegram from Russel today saying that White had secured
the services of Pareja and another man whose name I do not recall as I left
the telegram in the office and am writing this from the house. Russel said he
was writing me about it.

While I am becoming somewhat reconciled to this individual existence
puttering along with one specimen after another I still “feel the call of the
wild” and should like to be out fighting again. I wonder if a man ever feels
satisfied after he had done something worth while. Even you from the remarks
in your last letter do not seem entirely content not to be out on the frontier.
However in your case you are doing a great thing in this history, a thing which
posterity is going to take pride in I am sure. I find some men here who know
and value your work as it ought to be, and who give you great credit for what
has been accomplished not only in yellow fever but in the malaria and other
public health work.

In as much as the I.H.B. did not go ahead with my offer to take up the
work again after they asked me to do so, I think there is very little likeli-
hood that I shall take up work of that sort again, as I can not very well re-
main idly on the waiting list. I must go ahead definitely with one thing or
another, and while I am here it is imperative to equip this laboratory and
develope the diagnostic side of it which I want to do, and make it a thing
not only for the making of money but a useful source of information. Even in
a place of this kind if ones eyes are kept open there are a great many things
to be learned, and interesting things do come up. Since returning I have seen
a case of madura foot, a case of myelogenous leukemia and a case of filariasis.
I must write Francis about the latter as he was especially interested in the
incidence of this condition here. This woman gives a history of coming from
Wisconsin, has lived a while in Montana, but in no other section in the south
than Florida. In the last few days I found a freak tapeworm, where two com-
plete (with the exception of the head) worms grew from the same segment.

The indications are that I shall be kept quite busy, and collections
are fair.

I will very greatly appreciate seeing the sections of the history, and
presume there is no prospect of my moving away from here for some time.
With the warmest affections from all the Hanson family,
